awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Migration-selection balance in the evolution of insecticide resistance in Aedes aegypti
awd_abstract_narration:
The study will investigate the relative roles of the pattern of insecticide applications and mosquito movement in the evolution and propagation of resistance in wild-caught Aedes aeygpti mosquitoes. Programs relying on heavy use of insecticides are now used for control. The effectiveness of insecticide-based control strategies is being threatened by the evolution of insecticide resistance. Resistance has increased globally yet the mechanisms behind this spread are still largely unknown. Insecticide application exerts a selection pressure, yet this pressure is not constant in time or space. Additionally, mosquitoes can spread resistance to new areas as populations mix. These mosquitos are a major public health problem as they transmit multiple viral diseases including dengue fever, chikungunya, and zika virus. The research will have notable broader impacts as it informs insecticide resistance management and will be helpful in developing novel mosquito control strategies.
The most common form of insecticide resistance in Aedes aegypti is driven by point mutations in the para-orthologous sodium channel gene, which confers resistance to pyrethroid insecticides. Named kdr for "knock-down resistance", these point mutations may carry a fitness cost, rendering the resistant individuals less fit in the absence of insecticide pressure. Variation in the location and timing of urban insecticide applications creates a patchy environment of insecticide-free refuges, where susceptible mosquitoes may gain a fitness advantage, and areas with insecticide, where only resistant mosquitoes survive. There is also variation in the quality of larval habitats, which leads to density-dependent competition between individuals for resources. Under this complex selection scenario, the relative fitness of genotypes may change based on the presence of insecticide or larval density. To better understand these dynamics, researchers will conduct cage experiments under semi-natural conditions to quantify the relative fitness of kdr genotypes exposed to all combinations of two different treatments: with versus without insecticide, and high versus low larval density. These experiments will contribute to understanding the selection dynamics of kdr in Aedes aegypti and help explain patterns of resistance frequencies observed in field populations over space and time.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to better understand some of the ecological mediators of pyrethroid resistance in Aedes aegypti, the main mosquito species responsible for transmitting dengue, zika, and chikungunya. There were two main questions: (1) how does intraspecific competition, measured through larval density, impact pyrethroid resistance genotype and phenotype in adults, and (2) given an absence of insecticide pressure, can pyrethroid susceptibility be restored in a highly resistant population?

To investigate the first question, we reared a resistant and susceptible population of Aedes aegypti under high and low larval density conditions and measured the resulting pyrethroid resistance phenotype as well as the frequency of two “knock-down resistance” (kdr) mutations that confer pyrethroid resistance, F1534C and V1016I. We found that the “resistant” population (characterized as such through the standard CDC bioassays and high frequencies of the kdr mutations) was no longer phenotypically resistant if reared with high larval density. The resulting adults became susceptible to insecticide, and furthermore, the frequency of the F1534C mutation in the adult population significantly decreased, suggesting a fitness cost to that mutation. These results are novel because previous research on insecticide resistance in mosquitoes that transmit disease had mainly focused on the genetic underpinnings of resistance and not on ecological factors, like larval competition, that could impact the evolution of resistance. Furthermore, the results suggest a gene x environment interaction, wherein a population with the same genetic background exhibits a different phenotype based on the environment in which it was reared. These findings have important implications for mosquito control in field populations: they suggest that eliminating breeding habitats, apart from simply reducing the opportunity for mosquitoes to lay eggs, could force mosquitoes to lay eggs in higher densities elsewhere, which could aid in insecticide resistance management.  

The second experiment in this project aimed to assess the feasibility of regaining susceptibility in a resistant population given the absence of insecticide pressure. Most resistance management strategies rely on techniques such as rotation of insecticides or the application of insecticides in a spatially mosaic pattern, with the assumption that the cessation of insecticide selection pressure will slow the evolution of resistance. However, there is little empirical evidence that this is the case, and furthermore, it assumes that there is a fitness cost to resistance. To address this question, we reared a highly resistant population of Aedes aeypti with and without insecticide pressure for 10 generations and found a significant loss of phenotypic resistance in the populations reared without insecticide. Additionally, we found a significant fitness cost to the F1534C mutation, aligning with the results from our first experiment. Not only does this lend support to current resistance management strategies, it provides strong evidence that susceptibility can be restored into populations.

Overall, this project has important broader impacts for public health. There are currently no widely available vaccines for dengue, zika, and chinkgunya, which are some of the most important mosquito-borne viruses at present. Insecticides are still the mainstay of Aedes aegypti control, and if they lose function, then we will be forced to create new insecticides or novel control tools. Understanding the factors that can potentially reduce the evolution of resistance in these mosquitoes is vital to reducing mosquito populations and consequently the overall burden of these diseases.

Apart from the public health importance of the project, this project has served as a training ground for two undergraduate students, one from Mexico and one from Puerto Rico, both of which are now enrolled in Master’s programs to study mosquito-borne disease and public health. It was also part of a PhD student’s dissertation; she is now continuing work on insecticide resistance in Anopheles, the mosquitoes that transmit malaria.  Both projects have been published in peer-reviewed open-access journals, making the results widely available.

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2018
Modified by: Gonzalo Vazquez Prokopec
